official-title.#text:
To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to encourage
		  teachers to pursue teaching science, technology, engineering, and math subjects
		  at elementary and secondary schools.

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the following
			 bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
National STEM Education Tax Incentive
			 for Teachers Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text:
Refundable credit
			 for portion of tuition paid for undergraduate education of certain
			 teachers

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
(relating to refundable credits) is amended by
			 inserting after
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the
			 Internal Revenue Code of 1986

header.#text:
Tuition for
				undergraduate education of certain teachers

text.#text:
In the case of an individual who is an eligible teacher
				for the taxable year, there shall be allowed as a credit against the tax
				imposed by this subtitle an amount equal to 10 percent of qualified
				undergraduate tuition paid by such individual.

The credit allowed by this section for any taxable year
				shall not exceed $1,000.

In the case of one of the first 5
				taxable years in which a teacher is an eligible teacher who teaches in an
				elementary school or a secondary school (as those terms are defined in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section
				9101 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:9101

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
,
				subparagraph (A) shall be applied by substituting

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: part A of title I of such Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/t:I/pt:A

text.#text:
No credit shall be allowed under this section
				for any taxable year after the 10th taxable year for which credit is allowed
				under this section.
For purposes of this section—

term.#tail:
means, with
				respect to a taxable year, any individual—

text.#text: The term

who is a full-time
				teacher, including a full-time substitute teacher, in any of grades
				kindergarten through 12th grade for the academic year ending in such taxable
				year,

who teaches primarily
				math, science, engineering, or technology courses in one or more of grades 9
				through 12 during such academic year, or

who teaches math, science,
				engineering, or technology courses in one or more of grades kindergarten
				through 8 during such academic year,

who, in the case
				that such individual is a middle or secondary school teacher, received a
				baccalaureate or similar degree with a major in mathematics, science,
				engineering, or technology from an institution of higher education, and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 9101(23) of the Elementary and Secondary
				Education Act of 1965
